<li id="cite_note-27"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-27">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFM._L._West1997">M. L. West (1997). <i>The east face of Helicon: west Asiatic elements in Greek poetry and myth</i>. Oxford: Clarendon Press. p. 451. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-815221-7" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-815221-7"><bdi>978-0-19-815221-7</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+east+face+of+Helicon%3A+west+Asiatic+elements+in+Greek+poetry+and+myth&amp;rft.place=Oxford&amp;rft.pages=451&amp;rft.pub=Clarendon+Press&amp;rft.date=1997&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-815221-7&amp;rft.au=M.+L.+West&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEurope"></span>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-davison-28"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-davison_28-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFDavidson,_Roderic_H.1960">Davidson, Roderic H. (1960). "Where is the Middle East?". <i>Foreign Affairs</i>. <b>38</b> (4): 665–675. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.2307%2F20029452" rel="nofollow">10.2307/20029452</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/JSTOR_(identifier)" title="JSTOR (identifier)">JSTOR</a> <a class="external text" href="//www.jstor.org/stable/20029452" rel="nofollow">20029452</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S2CID_(identifier)" title="S2CID (identifier)">S2CID</a> <a class="external text" href="https://api.semanticscholar.org/CorpusID:157454140" rel="nofollow">157454140</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Foreign+Affairs&amp;rft.atitle=Where+is+the+Middle+East%3F&amp;rft.volume=38&amp;rft.issue=4&amp;rft.pages=665-675&amp;rft.date=1960&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fapi.semanticscholar.org%2FCorpusID%3A157454140%23id-name%3DS2CID&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.jstor.org%2Fstable%2F20029452%23id-name%3DJSTOR&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.2307%2F20029452&amp;rft.au=Davidson%2C+Roderic+H.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEurope"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-29"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-29">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The map shows one of the most commonly accepted delineations of the geographical boundaries of Europe, as used by <a href="/wiki/National_Geographic_Society" title="National Geographic Society">National Geographic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Encyclop%C3%A6dia_Britannica" title="Encyclopædia Britannica">Encyclopædia Britannica</a>. Whether countries are considered in Europe or Asia can vary in sources, for example in the classification of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/CIA_World_Factbook" title="CIA World Factbook">CIA World Factbook</a> or that of the <a href="/wiki/BBC" title="BBC">BBC</a>. Certain countries in Europe, such as France, have <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_countries_spanning_more_than_one_continent#Non-contiguous" title="List of countries spanning more than one continent">territories lying geographically outside Europe</a>, but which are nevertheless considered integral parts of that country.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Encarta-30"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Encarta_30-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Encarta_30-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation encyclopaedia cs1" id="CITEREFMicrosoft_Encarta_Online_Encyclopaedia_2007">Microsoft Encarta Online Encyclopaedia 2007. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20091028013857/http://encarta.msn.com/encyclopedia_761570768/Europe.html" rel="nofollow"><i>Europe</i></a>. Archived from <a class="external text" href="https://encarta.msn.com/encyclopaedia_761570768/Europe.html" rel="nofollow">the original</a> on 28 October 2009<span class="reference-accessdate">. </li>
<li id="cite_note-31"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-31">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Falconer, William; Falconer, Thomas. <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=B3Q29kWRdtgC&amp;pg=PA50" rel="nofollow"><i>Dissertation on St. Paul's Voyage</i></a> <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20170327020614/https://books.google.com/books?id=B3Q29kWRdtgC&amp;pg=PA50" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> 2017-03-27 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a>, BiblioLife (BiblioBazaar), 1872. <li id="cite_note-39"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-39">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><i><a href="/wiki/Geography_(Ptolemy)" title="Geography (Ptolemy)">Geographia</a></i> 7.5.6 (ed. "And [Asia] is connected to Europe by the land-strait between Lake Maiotis and the Sarmatian Ocean where the river Tanais crosses through."</span>

<li id="cite_note-Pocock2002-40"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Pocock2002_40-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Pocock2002_40-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFJ._G._A._Pocock2002"><a href="/wiki/J._G._A._Pocock" title="J. <li id="cite_note-45"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-45">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFDavies1996">Davies, Norman (1996). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=jrVW9W9eiYMC&amp;pg=PA8" rel="nofollow"><i>Europe: A History</i></a>. p. 8. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-820171-7" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-820171-7"><bdi>978-0-19-820171-7</bdi></a>. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20200801123242/https://books.google.com/books?id=jrVW9W9eiYMC&amp;pg=PA8" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on 1 August 2020<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-63"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-63">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">42.7–41.5 ka (<a href="/wiki/68%E2%80%9395%E2%80%9399.7_rule" title="68–95–99.7 rule">1σ CI</a>).
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFDouka2012">Douka, Katerina;  et al. (2012). <li id="cite_note-Borza-64"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Borza_64-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation cs2" id="CITEREFBorza1992">Borza, E.N. <li id="cite_note-Strauss2005-80"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Strauss2005_80-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFStrauss2005">Strauss, Barry (2005). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=nQFtMcD5dOsC" rel="nofollow"><i>The Battle of Salamis: The Naval Encounter That Saved Greece – and Western Civilization</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-90"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-90">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFHunter2004">Hunter, Shireen;  et al. (2004). <i>Islam in Russia: The Politics of Identity and Security</i>. M.E. Sharpe. p. 3. <q>(..) It is difficult to establish exactly when Islam first appeared in Russia because the lands that Islam penetrated early in its expansion were not part of Russia at the time, but were later incorporated into the expanding Russian Empire. Islam reached the Caucasus region in the middle of the seventh century as part of the Arab <a href="/wiki/Muslim_conquest_of_Persia" title="Muslim conquest of Persia">conquest</a> of the Iranian Sassanian Empire.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Islam+in+Russia%3A+The+Politics+of+Identity+and+Security&amp;rft.pages=3&amp;rft.pub=M.E.+Sharpe&amp;rft.date=2004&amp;rft.aulast=Hunter&amp;rft.aufirst=Shireen&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEurope"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-DuikerSpielvogel2010-105"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-DuikerSpielvogel2010_105-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFDuikerSpielvogel2010">Duiker, William J.; Spielvogel, Jackson J. (2010). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=UJpI18JaEL0C&amp;pg=PA330" rel="nofollow"><i>The Essential World History</i></a>. Cengage Learning. p. 330. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-495-90227-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-495-90227-0"><bdi>978-0-495-90227-0</bdi></a>. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20130511203023/http://books.google.com/books?id=UJpI18JaEL0C&amp;pg=PA330" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on 11 May 2013<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">20 January</span> 2013</span>. <q>The Byzantine Empire also interacted with the world of Islam to its east and the new European civilization of the west. Both interactions proved costly and ultimately fatal.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Essential+World+History&amp;rft.pages=330&amp;rft.pub=Cengage+Learning&amp;rft.date=2010&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-495-90227-0&amp;rft.aulast=Duiker&amp;rft.aufirst=William+J.&amp;rft.au=Spielvogel%2C+Jackson+J.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DUJpI18JaEL0C%26pg%3DPA330&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEurope"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Findlay2006-106"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Findlay2006_106-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFFindlay2006">Findlay, Ronald (2006). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=VOE-sRivB6kC&amp;pg=PA179" rel="nofollow"><i>Eli Heckscher, International Trade, And Economic History</i></a>. MIT Press. pp. 178–179. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-262-06251-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-262-06251-0"><bdi>978-0-262-06251-0</bdi></a>. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20130511210105/http://books.google.com/books?id=VOE-sRivB6kC&amp;pg=PA179" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on 11 May 2013<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">20 January</span> 2013</span>. <q>These Christian allies did not accept the authority of Byzantium, and the Fourth Crusade that sacked Constantinople and established the so-called Latin Empire that lasted until 1261 was a fatal wound from which the empire never recovered until its fall at the hands of the Ottoman Turks in 1453 (Queller and Madden 1997).</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Eli+Heckscher%2C+International+Trade%2C+And+Economic+History&amp;rft.pages=178-179&amp;rft.pub=MIT+Press&amp;rft.date=2006&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-262-06251-0&amp;rft.aulast=Findlay&amp;rft.aufirst=Ronald&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DVOE-sRivB6kC%26pg%3DPA179&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEurope"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Browning1992-107"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Browning1992_107-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFBrowning1992">Browning, Robert (1992). <span class="cs1-lock-registration" title="Free registration required"><a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/byzantineempire0000brow" rel="nofollow"><i>The Byzantine Empire</i></a></span> (Revised ed.). CUA Press. p. <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/byzantineempire0000brow/page/253" rel="nofollow">253</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-8132-0754-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-8132-0754-4"><bdi>978-0-8132-0754-4</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">20 January</span> 2013</span>. <q>And though the final blow was struck by the Ottoman Turks, it can plausibly be argued that the fatal injury was inflicted by the Latin crusaders in 1204.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Byzantine+Empire&amp;rft.pages=253&amp;rft.edition=Revised&amp;rft.pub=CUA+Press&amp;rft.date=1992&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-8132-0754-4&amp;rft.aulast=Browning&amp;rft.aufirst=Robert&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Fbyzantineempire0000brow&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEurope"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Byfield2008-108"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Byfield2008_108-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFByfield2008">Byfield, Ted (2008). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=o8hJgj5q5IEC&amp;pg=PA136" rel="nofollow"><i>A Glorious Disaster: A.D. 1100 to 1300: The Crusades: Blood, Valor, Iniquity, Reason, Faith</i></a>. Christian History Project. p. 136. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-9689873-7-7" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-9689873-7-7"><bdi>978-0-9689873-7-7</bdi></a>. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20130511204709/http://books.google.com/books?id=o8hJgj5q5IEC&amp;pg=PA136" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on 11 May 2013<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">20 January</span> 2013</span>. <q>continue to stand for another 250 before ultimately falling to the Muslim Turks, but it had been irrevocably weakened by the Fourth Crusade.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+Glorious+Disaster%3A+A.D.+1100+to+1300%3A+The+Crusades%3A+Blood%2C+Valor%2C+Iniquity%2C+Reason%2C+Faith&amp;rft.pages=136&amp;rft.pub=Christian+History+Project&amp;rft.date=2008&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-9689873-7-7&amp;rft.aulast=Byfield&amp;rft.aufirst=Ted&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Do8hJgj5q5IEC%26pg%3DPA136&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEurope"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Golna2004-109"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Golna2004_109-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFGolna2004">Golna, Cornelia (2004). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=xHXGa8HSQIQC&amp;pg=PA424" rel="nofollow"><i>City of Man's Desire: A Novel of Constantinople</i></a>. Go-Bos Press. p. 424. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-90-804114-4-9" title="Special:BookSources/978-90-804114-4-9"><bdi>978-90-804114-4-9</bdi></a>. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20130511214428/http://books.google.com/books?id=xHXGa8HSQIQC&amp;pg=PA424" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on 11 May 2013<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">20 January</span> 2013</span>. <q>1204 The Fourth Crusade sacks Constantinople, destroying and pillaging many of its treasures, fatally weakening the empire both economically and militarily</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=City+of+Man%27s+Desire%3A+A+Novel+of+Constantinople&amp;rft.pages=424&amp;rft.pub=Go-Bos+Press&amp;rft.date=2004&amp;rft.isbn=978-90-804114-4-9&amp;rft.aulast=Golna&amp;rft.aufirst=Cornelia&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DxHXGa8HSQIQC%26pg%3DPA424&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEurope"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Powell2001-110"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Powell2001_110-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFPowell2001">Powell, John (2001). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=lBYZAQAAIAAJ" rel="nofollow"><i>Magill's Guide to Military History: A-Cor</i></a>. Salem Press. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-89356-015-7" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-89356-015-7"><bdi>978-0-89356-015-7</bdi></a>. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20130511212456/http://books.google.com/books?id=lBYZAQAAIAAJ" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on 11 May 2013<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">20 January</span> 2013</span>. <q>However, the fifty-seven years of plunder that followed made the Byzantine Empire, even when it retook the capital in 1261, genuinely weak. Beginning in 1222, the empire was further weakened by a civil war that lasted until 1355. ... When the Ottomans overran their lands and besieged Constantinople in 1453, sheer poverty and weakness were the causes of the capital city's final fall.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Magill%27s+Guide+to+Military+History%3A+A-Cor&amp;rft.pub=Salem+Press&amp;rft.date=2001&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-89356-015-7&amp;rft.aulast=Powell&amp;rft.aufirst=John&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DlBYZAQAAIAAJ&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEurope"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Irvin2002-111"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Irvin2002_111-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFIrvin2002">Irvin, Dale T. (10 January 2002). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=C2akvQfa-QMC&amp;pg=PA405" rel="nofollow"><i>History of the World Christian Movement: Volume 1: Earliest Christianity To 1453</i></a>. Continuum International Publishing Group. p. 405. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-567-08866-6" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-567-08866-6"><bdi>978-0-567-08866-6</bdi></a>. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20130511205749/http://books.google.com/books?id=C2akvQfa-QMC&amp;pg=PA405" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on 11 May 2013<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">20 January</span> 2013</span>. <q>Not only did the fourth crusade further harden the resentments Greek-speaking Christians felt toward the Latin West, but it further weakened the empire of Constantinople, many say fatally so. After the restoration of Greek imperial rule the city survived as the capital of Byzantium for another two centuries, but it never fully recovered.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=History+of+the+World+Christian+Movement%3A+Volume+1%3A+Earliest+Christianity+To+1453&amp;rft.pages=405&amp;rft.pub=Continuum+International+Publishing+Group&amp;rft.date=2002-01-10&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-567-08866-6&amp;rft.aulast=Irvin&amp;rft.aufirst=Dale+T.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DC2akvQfa-QMC%26pg%3DPA405&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEurope"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Frucht2004-112"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Frucht2004_112-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFFrucht2004">Frucht, Richard C. (2004). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=lVBB1a0rC70C&amp;pg=PA856" rel="nofollow"><i>Eastern Europe: An Introduction to the People, Lands, and Culture</i></a>. ABC-CLIO. p. 856. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-57607-800-6" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-57607-800-6"><bdi>978-1-57607-800-6</bdi></a>. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20130511213734/http://books.google.com/books?id=lVBB1a0rC70C&amp;pg=PA856" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on 11 May 2013<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">20 January</span> 2013</span>. <q>Although the empire was revived, the events of 1204 had so weakened Byzantium that it was no longer a great power.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Eastern+Europe%3A+An+Introduction+to+the+People%2C+Lands%2C+and+Culture&amp;rft.pages=856&amp;rft.pub=ABC-CLIO&amp;rft.date=2004&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-57607-800-6&amp;rft.aulast=Frucht&amp;rft.aufirst=Richard+C.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DlVBB1a0rC70C%26pg%3DPA856&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEurope"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-DuikerSpielvogel2010v2-113"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-DuikerSpielvogel2010v2_113-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFDuikerSpielvogel2010">Duiker, William J.; Spielvogel, Jackson J. (2010). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=UJpI18JaEL0C&amp;pg=PA386" rel="nofollow"><i>The Essential World History</i></a>. Cengage Learning. p. 386. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-495-90227-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-495-90227-0"><bdi>978-0-495-90227-0</bdi></a>. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20130511220210/http://books.google.com/books?id=UJpI18JaEL0C&amp;pg=PA386" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on 11 May 2013<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">20 January</span> 2013</span>. <q>Later they established themselves in the Anatolian peninsula at the expense of the Byzantine Empire. ... The Byzantines, however, had been severely weakened by the sack of Constantinople in the Fourth Crusade (in 1204) and the Western occupation of much of the empire for the next half century.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Essential+World+History&amp;rft.pages=386&amp;rft.pub=Cengage+Learning&amp;rft.date=2010&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-495-90227-0&amp;rft.aulast=Duiker&amp;rft.aufirst=William+J.&amp;rft.au=Spielvogel%2C+Jackson+J.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DUJpI18JaEL0C%26pg%3DPA386&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEurope"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-natgeo_211-114"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-natgeo_211_114-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">National Geographic, 211.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Peters2006-115"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Peters2006_115-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFPeters2006">Peters, Ralph (29 August 2006). <span class="cs1-lock-registration" title="Free registration required"><a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/newgloryexpandin00pete" rel="nofollow"><i>New Glory: Expanding America's Global Supremacy</i></a></span>. Sentinel. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-59523-030-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-59523-030-0"><bdi>978-1-59523-030-0</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">20 January</span> 2013</span>. <q>Western Christians, not Muslims, fatally crippled Byzantine power and opened Islam's path into the West.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=New+Glory%3A+Expanding+America%27s+Global+Supremacy&amp;rft.pub=Sentinel&amp;rft.date=2006-08-29&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-59523-030-0&amp;rft.aulast=Peters&amp;rft.aufirst=Ralph&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Fnewgloryexpandin00pete&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEurope"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Chronicles-116"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Chronicles_116-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=Ay0RAQAAMAAJ" rel="nofollow"><i>Chronicles</i></a>. Rockford Institute. 2005. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20130511220240/http://books.google.com/books?id=Ay0RAQAAMAAJ" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on 11 May 2013<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">20 January</span> 2013</span>. <q>two-and-a-half centuries to recover from the Fourth Crusade before the Ottomans finally took Constantinople in 1453, ... They fatally wounded Byzantium, which was the main cause of its weakened condition when the Muslim onslaught came. Even on the eve of its final collapse, the precondition for any Western help was submission in Florence.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Chronicles&amp;rft.pub=Rockford+Institute&amp;rft.date=2005&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DAy0RAQAAMAAJ&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEurope"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Klyuch1-117"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Klyuch1_117-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFKlyuchevsky1987">Klyuchevsky, Vasily (1987). <a class="external text" href="http://www.kulichki.com/inkwell/text/special/history/kluch/kluch16.htm" rel="nofollow"><i>The course of the Russian history</i></a>. v.1: "Myslʹ. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-5-244-00072-6" title="Special:BookSources/978-5-244-00072-6"><bdi>978-5-244-00072-6</bdi></a>. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20071024124216/http://www.kulichki.com/inkwell/text/special/history/kluch/kluch16.htm" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on 24 October 2007<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-129"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-129">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://www.infoplease.com/cig/dangerous-diseases-epidemics/bubonic-plague.html" rel="nofollow">"Epidemics of the Past: Bubonic Plague — Infoplease.com"</a>. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">3 November</span> 2008</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Epidemics+of+the+Past%3A+Bubonic+Plague+%E2%80%94+Infoplease.com&amp;rft.pub=Infoplease.com&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.infoplease.com%2Fcig%2Fdangerous-diseases-epidemics%2Fbubonic-plague.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEurope"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-Revill-130"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Revill_130-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFRevill2004">Revill, Jo (16 May 2004). <a class="external text" href="https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2004/may/16/health.books" rel="nofollow">"Black Death blamed on man, not rats | UK news | The Observer"</a>. <i>The Observer</i>. <li id="cite_note-157"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-157">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFLukowski2014"><a href="/wiki/Jerzy_Lukowski" title="Jerzy Lukowski">Lukowski, Jerzy</a> (2014). <a class="external text" href="https://www.google.com.au/books/edition/The_Partitions_of_Poland_1772_1793_1795/Zm3XAwAAQBAJ?hl=en&amp;gbpv=0" rel="nofollow"><i>The Partitions of Poland 1772, 1793, 1795</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-158"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-158">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">W.G. Clarence-Smith (2006). "<i><a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=nQbylEdqJKkC" rel="nofollow">Islam And The Abolition Of Slavery</a> <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20160429200313/https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&amp;lr=&amp;id=nQbylEdqJKkC&amp;f=false" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> 2016-04-29 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a></i>". A compilation of estimates indicates that Crimean Tartars seized about 1,750,000 Ukrainians, Poles, and Russians from 1468 to 1694."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-159"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-159">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFHunt2003">Hunt, Shelby D. (2003). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=07lchJbdWGgC&amp;pg=PA18" rel="nofollow"><i>Controversy in marketing theory: for reason, realism, truth, and objectivity</i></a>. M.E. Sharpe. p. 18. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-7656-0932-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-7656-0932-8"><bdi>978-0-7656-0932-8</bdi></a>. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20220319180326/https://books.google.com/books?id=07lchJbdWGgC&amp;pg=PA18" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on 19 March 2022<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-240"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-240">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="nofollow">"Present and future Köppen-Geiger climate classification maps at 1-km resolution"</a>. <i>Scientific Data</i>. <b>5</b>: 180214. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bibcode_(identifier)" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1038%2Fsdata.2018.214" rel="nofollow">10.1038/sdata.2018.214</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PMC_(identifier)" title="PMC (identifier)">PMC</a> <span class="cs1-lock-free" title="Freely accessible"><a class="external text" href="//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6207062" rel="nofollow">6207062</a></span>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PMID_(identifier)" title="PMID (identifier)">PMID</a> <a class="external title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Scientific+Data&amp;rft.atitle=Present+and+future+K%C3%B6ppen-Geiger+climate+classification+maps+at+1-km+resolution&amp;rft.volume=5&amp;rft.pages=180214&amp;rft.date=2018-10-30&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC6207062%23id-name%3DPMC&amp;rft_id=info%3Apmid%2F30375988&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1038%2Fsdata.2018.214&amp;rft_id=info%3Abibcode%2F2018NatSD...580214B&amp;rft.aulast=Beck&amp;rft.aufirst=Hylke+E.&amp;rft.au=Zimmermann%2C+Niklaus+E.&amp;rft.au=McVicar%2C+Tim+R.&amp;rft.au=Vergopolan%2C+Noemi&amp;rft.au=Berg%2C+Alexis&amp;rft.au=Wood%2C+Eric+F.&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC6207062&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEurope"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-256"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-256">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Some data refers to IMF staff estimates but some are actual figures for href="http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/weo/2017/02/weodata/weorept.aspx?sy=2016&amp;ey=2016&amp;scsm=1&amp;ssd=1&amp;sort=country&amp;ds=.&amp;br=1&amp;c=512%2C672%2C914%2C946%2C612%2C137%2C614%2C546%2C311%2C962%2C213%2C674%2C911%2C676%2C193%2C548%2C122%2C556%2C912%2C678%2C313%2C181%2C419%2C867%2C513%2C682%2C316%2C684%2C913%2C273%2C124%2C868%2C339%2C921%2C638%2C948%2C514%2C943%2C218%2C686%2C963%2C688%2C616%2C518%2C223%2C728%2C516%2C836%2C918%2C558%2C748%2C138%2C618%2C196%2C624%2C278%2C522%2C692%2C622%2C694%2C156%2C142%2C626%2C449%2C628%2C564%2C228%2C565%2C924%2C283%2C233%2C853%2C632%2C288%2C636%2C293%2C634%2C566%2C238%2C964%2C662%2C182%2C960%2C359%2C423%2C453%2C935%2C968%2C128%2C922%2C611%2C714%2C321%2C862%2C243%2C135%2C248%2C716%2C469%2C456%2C253%2C722%2C642%2C942%2C643%2C718%2C939%2C724%2C644%2C576%2C819%2C936%2C172%2C961%2C132%2C813%2C646%2C199%2C648%2C733%2C915%2C184%2C134%2C524%2C652%2C361%2C174%2C362%2C328%2C364%2C258%2C732%2C656%2C366%2C654%2C734%2C336%2C144%2C263%2C146%2C268%2C463%2C532%2C528%2C944%2C923%2C176%2C738%2C534%2C578%2C536%2C537%2C429%2C742%2C433%2C866%2C178%2C369%2C436%2C744%2C136%2C186%2C343%2C925%2C158%2C869%2C439%2C746%2C916%2C926%2C664%2C466%2C826%2C112%2C542%2C111%2C967%2C298%2C443%2C927%2C917%2C846%2C544%2C299%2C941%2C582%2C446%2C474%2C666%2C754%2C668%2C698&amp;s=NGDPDPC&amp;grp=0&amp;a=&amp;pr.x=50&amp;pr.y=13" <li id="cite_note-294"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-294">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.vatican.va/content/john-paul-ii/en/motu_proprio/documents/hf_jp-ii_motu-proprio_01101999_co-patronesses-europe.html" rel="nofollow">"Spes Aedificandi"</a>. <i>The Holy See</i>. 1 October 1999. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20220301023956/https://www.vatican.va/content/john-paul-ii/en/motu_proprio/documents/hf_jp-ii_motu-proprio_01101999_co-patronesses-europe.html" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on 1 March 2022<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-Caltron_J.H_Hayas-304"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Caltron_J.H_Hayas_304-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Caltron J.H Hayas, <i>Christianity and Western Civilization</i> (1953), Stanford University Press, p. 2: That certain distinctive features of our Western civilization — the civilization of western Europe and of America— have been shaped chiefly by Judaeo – Graeco – Christianity, Catholic and Protestant.</span>

<li id="cite_note-How_The_Catholic_Church_Built_Western_Civilization-306"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-How_The_Catholic_Church_Built_Western_Civilization_306-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Thomas E. <li id="cite_note-UN_WUP_2016-311"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-UN_WUP_2016_311-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-UN_WUP_2016_311-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://www.un.org/en/development/desa/population/publications/pdf/urbanization/the_worlds_cities_in_2016_data_booklet.pdf" rel="nofollow">"The World's Cities in 2016"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>. 2016. p. 11. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20171001173328/http://www.un.org/en/development/desa/population/publications/pdf/urbanization/the_worlds_cities_in_2016_data_booklet.pdf" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span> from the original on 1 October 2017<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">30 July</span> 2022</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=The+World%27s+Cities+in+2016&amp;rft.pages=11&amp;rft.pub=United+Nations&amp;rft.date=2016&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.un.org%2Fen%2Fdevelopment%2Fdesa%2Fpopulation%2Fpublications%2Fpdf%2Furbanization%2Fthe_worlds_cities_in_2016_data_booklet.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEurope"></span></span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-315"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-315">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFDine2010">Dine, Philip; and Seán Crosson (2010). <i>Sport, Representation and Evolving Identities in Europe</i>. <li id="cite_note-Vishnevsky-316"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Vishnevsky_316-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFVishnevsky2000">Vishnevsky, Anatoly (15 August 2000). <a class="external text" href="https://www.un.org/esa/population/publications/popdecline/vishnevsky.pdf" rel="nofollow">"Replacement Migration: Is it a solution for Russia?"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <i>Expert Group Meeting on Policy Responses to Population Ageing and Population Decline /UN/POP/PRA/2000/14</i>. United Nations Population Division, Department of Economic and Social Affairs. pp. 6, 10. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20170829152839/http://www.un.org/esa/population/publications/popdecline//vishnevsky.pdf" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span> from the original on 29 August 2017<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">14 January</span> 2008</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Expert+Group+Meeting+on+Policy+Responses+to+Population+Ageing+and+Population+Decline+%2FUN%2FPOP%2FPRA%2F2000%2F14&amp;rft.atitle=Replacement+Migration%3A+Is+it+a+solution+for+Russia%3F&amp;rft.pages=6%2C+10&amp;rft.date=2000-08-15&amp;rft.aulast=Vishnevsky&amp;rft.aufirst=Anatoly&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.un.org%2Fesa%2Fpopulation%2Fpublications%2Fpopdecline%2Fvishnevsky.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEurope"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-317"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-317">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UN" title="UN">UN</a> Statistics Department <a class="external autonumber" href="http://unstats.un.org/unsd/methods/m49/m49regin.htm" rel="nofollow">[4]</a> <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20181226004109/https://unstats.un.org/unsd/methods/m49/m49regin.htm" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> 2018-12-26 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a> places Azerbaijan in <a href="/wiki/Western_Asia" title="Western Asia">Western Asia</a> for statistical convenience <a class="external autonumber" href="http://unstats.un.org/unsd/methods/m49/m49.htm" rel="nofollow">[5]</a> <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20170711220015/https://unstats.un.org/unsd/methods/m49/m49.htm" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> 2017-07-11 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a>: "The assignment of countries or areas to specific groupings is for statistical convenience and does not imply any assumption regarding political or other affiliation of countries or territories." The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/CIA_World_Factbook" title="CIA World Factbook">CIA World Factbook</a> <a class="external autonumber" href="https://www.cia.gov/the-world-factbook/countries/azerbaijan/" rel="nofollow">[6]</a> <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20210127171042/https://www.cia.gov/the-world-factbook/countries/azerbaijan/" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> 2021-01-27 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a> places Azerbaijan in South Western Asia, with a small portion north of the Caucasus range in Europe. <a class="external text" href="http://education.nationalgeographic.com/education/mapping/outline-map/?map=Azerbaijan&amp;ar_a=1" rel="nofollow">National Geographic</a> <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20120119140030/http://education.nationalgeographic.com/education/mapping/outline-map/?map=Azerbaijan&amp;ar_a=1" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> 19 January 2012 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a> and <i><a class="external text" href="https://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/230186/Azerbaijan" rel="nofollow">Encyclopædia Britannica</a> <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20220730042224/https://www.britannica.com/place/Georgia" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> 2022-07-30 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a></i> also place Georgia in Asia.</span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-W.Asia-320"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-W.Asia_320-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">UN</a> Statistics Department <a class="external autonumber" href="http://unstats.un.org/unsd/methods/m49/m49regin.htm" rel="nofollow">[16]</a> <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20181226004109/https://unstats.un.org/unsd/methods/m49/m49regin.htm" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> 2018-12-26 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a> places Georgia in <a href="/wiki/Western_Asia" title="Western Asia">Western Asia</a> for statistical convenience <a class="external autonumber" href="http://unstats.un.org/unsd/methods/m49/m49.htm" rel="nofollow">[17]</a> <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20170711220015/https://unstats.un.org/unsd/methods/m49/m49.htm" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> 2017-07-11 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a>: "The assignment of countries or areas to specific groupings is for statistical convenience and does not imply any assumption regarding political or other affiliation of countries or territories." The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/CIA_World_Factbook" title="CIA World Factbook">CIA World Factbook</a> <a class="external autonumber" href="https://www.cia.gov/the-world-factbook/countries/georgia/" rel="nofollow">[18]</a> <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20210204222544/https://www.cia.gov/the-world-factbook/countries/georgia/" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> 2021-02-04 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a>, <a class="external text" href="http://www.nationalgeographic.com/xpeditions/atlas/index.html?Parent=asia&amp;Rootmap=georgi&amp;Mode=d&amp;SubMode=w" rel="nofollow">National Geographic</a> <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20201211151904/http://www.nationalgeographic.com/xpeditions/atlas/index.html?Parent=asia&amp;Rootmap=georgi&amp;Mode=d&amp;SubMode=w" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> 2020-12-11 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a>, and <i><a class="external text" href="https://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/230186/Georgia" rel="nofollow">Encyclopædia Britannica</a> <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20150426041425/http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/230186/Georgia" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> 2015-04-26 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a></i> also place Georgia in Asia.</span>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Sources">Sources</span></h2>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/National_Geographic_Society" title="National Geographic Society">National Geographic Society</a> (2005). <i>National Geographic Visual History of the World</i>. <li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFBullietCrossleyHeadrickHirsch2011">Bulliet, Richard; Crossley, Pamela; Headrick, Daniel; Hirsch, Steven; Johnson, Lyman (2011). <i>The Earth and Its Peoples, Brief Edition</i>. Vol. 1. <ul><li><a href="/wiki/Faroe_Islands" title="Faroe Islands">Faroe Islands</a><sup>3</sup>

</div></td></tr><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%">United Kingdom</th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-odd" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em"></div><table class="nowraplinks navbox-subgroup" style="border-spacing:0"><tbody><tr><td class="navbox-list navbox-even" colspan="2" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Akrotiri_and_Dhekelia" title="Akrotiri and Dhekelia">Akrotiri and Dhekelia</a><sup>2</sup> (Sovereign Base Areas)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Gibraltar" title="Gibraltar">Gibraltar</a> (<a href="/wiki/British_Overseas_Territories" title="British Overseas Territories">British Overseas Territory</a>)</li></ul>
</div></td></tr><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%"><a href="/wiki/Crown_Dependencies" title="Crown Dependencies">Crown Dependencies</a></th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-odd" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em">

</div></td></tr></tbody></table><div></div></td></tr></tbody></table><div></div></td></tr><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%"><div style="display: inline-block; line-height: 1.2em; padding: .1em 0;">Special areas<br/>of internal<br/>sovereignty</div></th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-odd" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em"></div><table class="nowraplinks navbox-subgroup" style="border-spacing:0"><tbody><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%">Finland</th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-even" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em">

</div></td></tr><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%">Norway</th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-odd" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Svalbard" title="Svalbard">Svalbard</a> (<a href="/wiki/Unincorporated_area" title="Unincorporated area">unincorporated area</a> subject to the <a href="/wiki/Svalbard_Treaty" title="Svalbard Treaty">Svalbard Treaty</a>)</li></ul>
</div></td></tr><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%">United Kingdom</th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-even" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Northern_Ireland" title="Northern Ireland">Northern Ireland</a> (<a href="/wiki/Countries_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Countries of the United Kingdom">country of the United Kingdom</a> subject to the <a href="/wiki/Good_Friday_Agreement" title="Good Friday Agreement">British-Irish Agreement</a>)</li></ul>
</div></td></tr></tbody></table><div></div></td></tr><tr><td class="navbox-abovebelow" colspan="3"><div><div class="hlist hlist-separated"><ul><li><sup>1</sup> Spans the conventional boundary between Europe and another continent.</li><li><sup>2</sup> Considered European for cultural, political and historical reasons but is geographically in Western Asia.</li><li><sup>3</sup> <a href="/wiki/Island#Oceanic_islands" title="Island">Oceanic islands</a> within the vicinity of Europe are usually grouped with the continent even though they are not situated on its continental shelf.</li></ul></div>
<ul><li><img alt="" class="noviewer" data-file-height="185" data-file-width="180" decoding="async" height="16" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/96/Symbol_category_class.svg/16px-Symbol_category_class.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/96/Symbol_category_class.svg/23px-Symbol_category_class.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/96/Symbol_category_class.svg/31px-Symbol_category_class.svg.png 2x" title="Category" width="16"/> <b><a href="/wiki/Category:Europe" title="Category:Europe">Category</a></b></li>

<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Danube" title="Danube">Danubian countries</a></li>

(pt-br)</a></li><li><a href="/wiki/Category:Articles_with_short_description" title="Category:Articles with short description">Articles with short description</a></li><li><a
